ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal about theory, the formulation and transmission of theory, and the  post WWII German theory tradition. I also developed as a philosophical/critical writer.
A sense of the main debates of German philosophy during the 60s.
Insights into intellectual history of post-war German theory scene

knowledge about the development and members of the Frankfurt School
skills to deconstruct historical generalizations about theory, philosophy, and other scholarly disciplines
insights about the nature of post-war German academia

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the syllabus was great, Prof Wetters was fantastic in discussions (super knowledgeable), and great generosity and engagement with students both via Canvas, email, and in-person. the course and the writing process for the two papers. The TF, Saurabh, was also likewise excellent and generous with his time for students. 

Weaknesses: none. At times, it felt a little intimidating to speak up in class discussion, but I think this was more a product of my internal fears than the actual dynamics of the class itself.

Prof. Wetters is an engaged and very knowledgeable seminar leader. He is very kind and capable in discussion, and he is always eager to offer help outside of class. The materials were interesting, and Prof. Wetters was usually very good about posting some historical background and intellectual context for the readings each week on Canvas. I think the Canvas discussions were quite nice as wellProf. Wetters was very enthusiastic about replying to our posts on there, which made posting feel more engaging and "worth it," so to speak. Sometimes I felt like the seminar discussion was a bit unstructured and could have benefited from more intervention from Prof. Wetters about the topic of discussion, or at least a round-up at the beginning of class of topics that people brought up in Canvas posts, which could serve as a more defined basis of discussion to start from.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely. See my reasons above (great prof/TF, interesting  syllabus) Especially if interested in philosophy/theory/continental philosophy. I did not have a great background in these things prior to the course, and I took a lot out of the class.

Yes, definitely. Kirk is a gem and the course is very well constructed. A good mix of historical perspective on this specific academic culture and consideration of their relevance to contemporary discourses of social science, left-wing politics, and philosophy.

Yes, but only if you're pretty sure you're interested in the topic, and/or if you like and have a lot of patience for doing readings and talking about intellectual history and a diverse range of philosophical+theoretical concepts anyways.
